commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Hold close to the heart  (3)
2. Things feared in the 80s and 90s?  (5)(5)
3. They're grated outdoors  (6)
4. Words on a statue honoring Washington  (4)(5)
5. Show that, uh, didn't win 43 of its 54 Emmy nominations  (4)


HUG
SPEED TRAPS
DRAINS
BEST ACTOR
LOST
Nipped right through that. I was a little confused on breadbox being toaster as I‚Äôm familiar with the old fashioned actual breadbox. Aloha all.
This was a good, easy Monday! Thanks!

As I read this and finished the puzzle, the LPGA is in the first ever 5 way sudden death. I thought it was funny, as the constructor of the puzzle, works with Professional Golfers and is probably at the tournament.

Ooh, Monday magic.
Make sure Show Overlays is turned on, kids, if solving on-line.

Lovely puzzle and a good worldplay column and constructor's notes: the analogy to winning a golf tournament as well as the other golf connections was very apt and amusing. May the  LPGA never play at Turnberry again, and I hope the LIV guys leave your tour alone, too. 

Had no idea that the mako shark could go faster than my Saab 900! I purchased it when it was only a five-year-old in 1990 from my know-it-all mother-in-law, who wanted a newer sedan. At first, I thought, "Awesome!" but before I had traveled the span of one mile, I started thinking "Does this car even have a pulse?" And my mother-in-law had split with my money like she was on the lam: took the US Air flight direct to Honolulu, sent us a postcard of her in a tutu on the beach, her red-nosed visage very merry from all the mojitos she had consumed. "Aloha all my Steeler fans back home!" she had written on the back. In time the car became my hated nemesis, and I was like a walking ATM for the jack-of-all-trades who worked on it. We still occasionally get a postcard from my dear mother-in-law from the yurt she's living in, where it's never nippy, never like being in a toaster, the moon never wanes, there's no wifi, so you can't do any ego-surfing but plenty of other kinds. If she ever invites us out there, which is doubtful, I'm there.

And that's my Saab story.

Sometimes when a puzzle's too easy
One wants one a little more teasy
But this Sunday I'm drowsy
(Well, I truly feel lousy)
Did you write this escape just to please me?

Thank you, Sue Fracker
This one is a cracker!

Got tripped up on the SW. Had TOTE crossing with TOTALUP and couldn't for the life of me figure out how to finish EGOSUO__

Took 45 seconds to resolve from the 3:45 mark
I done did this puzz
Might have had an all-time record time if not for a shocking number of typos. I really have to stop doing these on my phone.

Is it still EGOSURFing if you only Google your own name to check that there are still no photographs of you on-line? 

Or is that NEGOSURFing?

Fastest Monday so far. Cute theme, but I was about to comment that it's too bad we can't enter the hyphens in a crossword about multi-hyphenates when low and behold, there they were!

I guess having us add the hyphens would make the puzzle way more difficult to construct because the hyphens would have to make sense in the crosses as well.

I enjoyed this puzzle.
This was nice and breezy. And last week was the week for Ayo Edebiri!

Always happy when SALT-N-PEPA comes up in any context. 

Here I go, here I go, here I go again‚Ä¶

"Are you still reading that book on punctuation?"
"No, hyphenished it."

("I'll wait for the movie. I hear it'll be a comma-dy.")

Congratulations on your second-published-hopefully-with-more-to-come grid, Ms. Fracker. AWESOMEly done! It was a pleasure to solve this MULTI-HYPHENATED puzzle. The themed revealer came as a delicious surprise; try as I might to figure out the theme, I didn't see it coming. Here's Stevie Wonder with his not-so-complimentary NOD to a KNOW-IT-ALL. https://youtu.be/uivvYGyQiow?si=9isPpN8-S5ZRfVLG ("Take my word, please beware Of a man that just don't give a care, no He's Misstra Know-It-All.")
Was on track for a record time, but got hung up on thinking of a dictionary as REFerence material, and not knowing my 1980s skaters too well. As ever, thank you for the puzzle!

How is it that MULTI-HYPHENATE has only one hyphen?

Thanks for the fun puzzle, Ms Fracker! I‚Äôm impressed that you construct using paper and pencil. Not many people do that anymore.
Very nice puzzle. Thanks.

Joel did brilliantly in today mini. 

A worthy example of the genre.
Nice Monday and no sign of a sophomore slump. Hope to see more from you in the future.
Congratulations on no.2, Sue. A lot of fun. Looking forward to no.3.
It was such a beautiful puzzle, very fitting for a Monday. Not too hard and not too easy. I look forward to Sue's third crossword!
Great job, Sue - a fun one for #841 on my current streak - from a friend of the Michigan Frackers ‚ù§Ô∏è

Lovely crossword.
Now I know to ask for oven MITTS and not oven gloves, as well as UMP for umpire, SEDAN for .... just a car (they're all just cars) and I know SNO-CAPS and the other one - froyo, is it?
Is MULTI-HYPHENATE actually used for talented people? 
Hershey's chocolate is usually referred in a rather negative way (I won't be more precise and offend people) compared with say Swiss or Belgian. Don't know what a KISS tastes like though.

Super fun puzzle this morning by a great constructor. Can't wait to see more from Sue.

Multi-hyphenates is such a lovely word that's not used enough in everyday conversations. Maybe this puzzle will change that among at least a select crew of NYT crossword aficionados üòâ.

It occurs to me that as we go through life we become multi-hyphenates as a  kind of beautiful rite of passage.

Some are by necessity: we learn to tie our shoes, drive a car, cook...

And some are because of life circumstances: we learn to soothe a crying baby, read a bedtime story (often reading upside down), comfort a hurting friend...

And others are by choice: learning to sew or knit, mastering a golf swing, playing an instrument...

There are so many talents that we take for granted in ourselves and others. This puzzle made me slow down for a minute and appreciate that fact. What a nice start to a Monday!
A fun start to the week, glad that Sue doesn‚Äôt consider herself a one hit wonder as we can hopefully look forward to more from her.

I love the mini.  I don't love that in the Android app one can't use a physical keyboard on the mini.  Why is that?  The keyboard works fine in Spelling Bee for Android.  The Apple app allows the keyboard on the mini.  I would mind it less if the on-screen keyboard weren't so unreliable.  I hope you fix it before I decide I'm too lazy and prideful to suffer a lousy time hunting-and-pecking and re-typing my way through a puzzle that is supposed to be short and sweet.

Quicker-than-usual...not a one-hit-wonder to be sure!

A great way to sweep out the cobwebs from the oft-used-x- word closet. But hey, that's not a problem for this master-of-none solver!!

You know texting multi-hyphenated words can be so time consuming, but it's so much fun to get to use them!

Thanks for a fun start to the week!

Lovely Monday!

Thank you Sue.

Keep ‚Äòem coming!
That was refreshing after Saturday and Sunday dragging out. A Camry is an urban icon in Australia. If they used them, there would be a picture of it next to Sedan in the dictionary.

Fun Monday puzzle. Had to work the crosses a bit all over the place before something dawned on me but that just made for a nice workout. And... the reveal was actually the last thing I worked out. That just made for a great finishing touch. Puzzle find today - a Wednesday from March 28, 2007 by Burton Clemans. Five 15 letter grid-spanning theme answers. One clue/answer example: "Harvests more Anjous than needed?" REAPSSPAREPEARS And the other theme answers: RATESARTESTEARS LARGEREGALGLARE TIMESEMITSMITES LEASTSTALETALES Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/28/2007&g=17&d=A And... that trick had been done once before. A Wednesday from June 21, 2000. That one had four 15 letter grid-spanning theme answers. A couple of examples: NEPALPLANEPANEL PAPERCAPERRECAP Here's the Xword Info link for that one: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/21/2000&g=44&d=A I'll shut up now. ...
well now i desperately want to get a pair of cats called vim and vigor

Cute. Now I have the one hit wonder I remember in my head: The Bird by the Trashmen.

See you soon, we hope, Sue.

MITTS!  Oven MITTS.  I got stuck on the rubber gloves, or the non-latex 'surgical' gloves I put on to handle chicken (because the least little nick in a finger gets infected at once regardless of brisk washing.)  TRIVETS? No, too long, and besides, more likely to be seen on the dining-room table.  Finally I just moved on, reminding myself that starting at 1A Never Works for MOL!

Rudolph's RED NOSE is a sore point.  The sycophantic herd of reindeer shunned him until they saw a personal advantage, after which they faked approval and acceptance like the hypocrites they were (and no doubt remained....as soon as the fog lifted, Rudy was non grata again.)  I hated that song from the first time I heard it at age FIVE or six...  

Goodness, it sounds like I woke up at 5 a.m. and read substack/email, wrote to both Senators and the Representative from  Mississippi, and fretted over how many books to take on our 4-day trip to visit friends in Arkansas (minimum of 2, but what if I want to abandon one and find myself Without A Book?  And don't say I can read one on my iPad--too heavy.)
If it sounds like I'm taking steroids, it's because I am.  Hand settling down nicely now; no idea what I did to get it so aggravated.... well, maybe I do know but don't want to admit it.

The little grey cells were quite smug this morning telling me "we got out of bed for this easy thing?!.  Well the joke's on them because they did not see the MULTIHYPHENATES theme until the very end (they did keep asking what was up).  

Hope they are more on the ball tomorrow morning.  

Like us dead tree solvers is there a subset (sub-set?) of pencil-and-paper constructors?  I sure hope so. 

Very well done and thanks!

Came here to comment on VIM and VIGOR, my future new kittens. Have been away for a while. 

I hope that by the time you read this, power will have been restored throughout Portugal and Spain. People are stuck on metro trains between stops. I bet it‚Äôs quite hot by now since it‚Äôs been over two hours.  

Silver lining: I‚Äôm going to start some prepping for real after this üò≥
Easy one today, nothing like that awful Terry Veg quiz a while back! Don't need to be reminded of that man thank you very much.

Don't forget to latch the YURT before you saddke up . . .

Hyphenation, 
where the words come apartin' from their pairs, 
Where Sue Fracker sounds, 
Still sound compond, 
But the dash fell out between the squares! 

Hyphenation, every night my little grid and I, 
Hope WIFI don't stall, 
Cause this KNOWITALL
Won't SEE a gold star in the sky

We know today's hyohens were banned 
And IMTHERE to OPTIN on Sue's plan

And when I SAYS, hey! MOTHERINLAW dont stay
I'm lettin' five REDNOSE MOHITOS astray
FIVEYEAROLD brain, 
(INEBRIATION?), 
HY-PH-E-NA-TI-O-N, 
HYPHENATION!
Just the breezy Monday I needed. Thank you Sue Fracker for this delight!

What a fun and breezy puzzle! I dashed my way through it üòâ This was number 1,360 in a row for me, so only 100 more to hit my 4 year streak!!

Well done, Sue! I‚Äôm looking forward to seeing more from you soon.

A lovely Monday puzzle for a lovely Monday in the UK. The sun is out (where have you been?) and allegedly will stay out all week.

Kindergarten age fooled me a tad. Kids start primary school at four here. 

This has restored my faith in my ability to complete/vaguely understand a crossword, after yesterday‚Äôs (for me) debacle.
For future reference (whenever they release my already-much-earlier post), my nemesis today is an emu.

Well sure, HPS can be printers and PCs, but also calculators. Mine is a 12C (financial) and it says 5318008.

Can emus read upside-down?
Two tries on my main comment already, can't imagine what emu-ed it.  I'm going to give it a rest.  Hopefully it will show up!
Nice puzzle, Sue!  Hopefully we'll see you back soon.
Toaster for ‚Äúbread box?‚Äù made me smile today

I was off to a strong start, so I decided to see if I could sprint to a Monday best. Unfortunately I got slowed down a bit by the bottom third of the puzzle, so I didn't quite make it -- I need to be 30 seconds faster! 4th fastest Monday since I started on XWStats about 7 months ago.
That was a cracker, Jacker!
That was the best set of constructor notes I believe I've ever seen. Great job Sue!

Great theme, slightly challenging for a Monday.

Please please please - could there be at least a temporary moratorium on all things "spa"?  I'm so sick of seeing it used as both an answer and a clue.  Not only is it trite, it's largely unrelatable for many.

Come back, Oreos (TM) - all is forgiven.  ;)

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

My nemesis fits the theme.
He‚Äôs a dirty rotten so-and-so.

(At Jack-Five, I was looking for a cribbage hand.)
Sue kinda killed it today, low key.

An off-the-cuff, cut-and-dried, blow-by-blow, play-by-play.

‚ÄúIn-your-face, puzzle!‚Äù, I thought, during my t√™te-√†-t√™te with the grid. ‚ÄúHonest-to-goodness, today‚Äôs the day. It‚Äôs do-or-die, puzzle; I‚Äôm going to guess your reveal. It‚Äôs one-on-one and I‚Äôm going to rope-a-dope you! An open-and-shut case! Dog-eat-dog! Life-or-death! In-your-face!"

There was no back-and-forth.

I filled in all but the reveal in short order, give-or-take, and began my trial-and-error. I thought, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll have this filled coast-to-coast in no time.‚Äù

But it was hit-and-miss, hunt-and-peck, touch-and-go. I tried to see the what connected the theme answers ‚Äì first words, last words, word initials ‚Äì to no avail; it was wall-to-wall perplexion.

I seem to have a blind spot for hyphens.

Dear reader, honest-to-goodness, there are many things I‚Äôm not, including hard-to-please, know-it-all, or stick-in-the-mud -- and many things I am, including left-of-center, occasionally tongue-in-cheek, and, I‚Äôd like to think, up-and-coming.

And yes, weak at guessing revealers, to be matter-of-fact. But it‚Äôs open-and-shut that I shall fight on, and one day my post will be a show-and-tell of a larger-than-life reveal-guessing success! I will join the rank-and-file of reveal conquerers!

Sue, point-of-fact, your puzzle was the perfect blend of fun and challenge ‚Äì made-to-order for me, and I loved it ‚Äì thank you!

An off-the-cuff, cut-and-dried, blow-by-blow, play-by-play.

‚ÄúIn-your-face, puzzle!‚Äù, I thought, during my t√™te-√†-t√™te with the grid.  ‚ÄúHonest-to-goodness, today‚Äôs the day.  It‚Äôs do-or-die, puzzle; I‚Äôm going to guess your reveal.  It‚Äôs one-on-one and I‚Äôm going to rope-a-dope you! An open-and-shut case! Dog-eat-dog! Life-or-death!  In-your-face!"

There was no back-and-forth.

I filled in all but the reveal in short order, give-or-take, and began my trial-and-error.  I thought, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll have this filled coast-to-coast in no time.‚Äù

But it was hit-and-miss, hunt-and-peck, touch-and-go.  I tried to see the what connected the theme answers ‚Äì first words, last words, word initials ‚Äì to no avail; it was wall-to-wall perplexion.  

I seem to have a blind spot for hyphens.

Dear reader, honest-to-goodness, there are many things I‚Äôm not, including hard-to-please, know-it-all, or stick-in-the-mud -- and many things I am, including left-of-center, occasionally tongue-in-cheek, and, I‚Äôd like to think, up-and-coming.  

And yes, weak at guessing revealers, to be matter-of-fact.  But it‚Äôs open-and-shut that I shall fight on, and one day my post will be a show-and-tell of a larger-than-life reveal-guessing success!  I will join the rank-and-file of reveal conquerers!

Sue, point-of-fact, your puzzle was the perfect blend of fun and challenge ‚Äì made-to-order for me, and I loved it ‚Äì thank you!

Before I got to the revealer I thought the theme was going in the direction of "unsolicited advice givers".

Solid Monday puzzle, and I enjoyed the constructor notes.

Lewis,

It seems your overuse of punctuation tripped the filter, 
but once a bird reviewed the posts, 
they made a Quick Escape.

Late puzzle find, inspired in a roundabout way by 11d - thought of a song about RUDOLPH the red-nosed reindeer. Anyway -- A Monday from August 13, 2018 by Lynn Lempel (one of my favorite constructors). The clue/answer that got me there: "Leave a lasting legacy ... or do worse at school" GODOWNINHISTORY And some others: "Succeed on the gridiron ... or invite a slap in the face" MAKEPASSES "Score in baseball ... or ruin some hose" GETARUN "Be lucky in Scrabble ... or come up short memorywise" DRAWABLANK And the reveal: "Start of a mixed message, as illustrated by 17-, 23-, 39- and 54-Across" GOODNEWSBADNEWS Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/13/2018&g=17&d=A ....
A new PB for me today! Just the pick-me-up I needed!

Unfamiliar with MULTIHYPHENATES as a reference to "Ones with many talents." So I learned something new today. Can't say I found the theme or the thematic entries AWESOME.

Was amazed as I effortlessly entered names like SETH, LETO, PEPA, OTERI, DEBI, EMMA and LOEW. Normally these slow me down, but today they just flew into the grid. No idea how or why---and likely not repeatable. Demonic possession?

I was so proud of myself for immediately getting  JACKOFALLTRADES as the revealer at 58A with no other entries filled in: I'm brilliant!

Imagine my surprise to learn that 17A was the exact same answer....  Hmm. 

D'oh!  Guess it's true that pride goeth before the fall. üòÇ

Smooth and fun solve otherwise.  Interesting to learn about LAM. I didn't fill it in right away because I hadn't heard of it other than "on the lam," as Sam writes about.

Strands #421

using this one for the mini... I managed to get it in 2 minutes and 45 seconds, but then I redid it and speed ran it. Got that in eleven seconds. 


This is also my first crossword comment so üëç
This is an impressive Monday. It felt like a Monday but had 15-letter crosses that would‚Äôve been well-positioned in a Saturday. Good job!
Did you all hear the Real ID is back in force May 7th? Terrible grammar; worse precedent.
Fun Monday puzzle to start my week off on a good note.  I got a chuckle out of the bread box clues.  Thanks for the fun puzzle, Ms. Fracker.
Cute puzzle, although I am unfamiliar with EGOSURF.

I never cease to be amazed and am forever grateful that these days we can sit at home and see world class performances of cultural treasures such as 15A whenever we want and at no cost.  And that‚Äôs just a fraction of what social media such as youtube can offer, if we have a mind to look for good stuff to watch or learn.

My fingers also have a mind of their own. (I wonder if they ever Google themselves when I'm asleep.) But I guess I don't care enough about my time to solve on paper, and I find the app so enjoyable.
@Beth I wander off the top row constantly. Anytime there‚Äôs an O or a P in an answer, I‚Äôm liable to hit the right arrow above it and start entering letters in the wrong space.

I guess I should clarify for those solving on paper that using the app (with overlays turned on I'm guessing), the hyphens appear between the words after you complete the puzzle.

"I guess having us add the hyphens would make the puzzle way more difficult to construct because the hyphens would have to make sense in the crosses as well." Beth, Remember this one? https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2024/12/29

@sotto voce :-)
@Martin Same for me!

@Eric Hougland

"How is it that MULTI-HYPHENATE has only one hyphen?"

And "non-hyphenated" is hyphenated. 

The beauty of the English language.

@sotto voce

Yes, and we drive on a parkway and park in a driveway.  We speak a paradoxical language indeed.

@Jane Wheelaghan A SEDAN is a specific type of car. You might know it as a saloon in England; like many other automotive terms, such as truck, hood and windshield, the American terms have counterparts in British English (boot, bonnet, windscreen). It gets its name from pre-automotive seating compartments that were carried by servants. In case you‚Äôre not aware of the various body types of cars, a SEDAN or saloon (which in the US means a bar or tavern) ia a vehicle with three separate segments: an engine compartment in front, a passenger compartment, and a storage compartment in the rear; a SEDAN also generally has four doors. Compare this to an SUV or station wagon (estate wagon), in which the passenger area and the storage area are continuous. You can seat people in the third row or put the seats down for more carrying space. A SEDAN is also characterized by three roof support columns; SUVS and wagons have four. A convertible has no fixed roof; a coupe or coup√© is similar to a SEDAN, but smaller and it generally has two doors. Other body types have existed in the past, but are no longer produced. For even more information: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedan_(automobile)

@Oikofuge

Hmm. Steve L's comment wasn't visible when I started typing mine. Apologies for the duplicate information, but I seem to have added a bit of etymology to the mix.

@Steve L
Thank you again!
What I meant by they are all cars, is that if I've said to  friend or family that I've got a new car, no-one has ever responded. "Is it a saloon or a hatchback" or whatever. There isn't an equivalent to coupe, although one might say '3-door' - the boot is counted as a door.
They know I would never buy an SUV, (once termed a Chelsea Tractor)

"What did you get?"
"A Renault Clio/a Toyota Yaris/Mercedes (not in this  lifetime!) etc
I might add that it's an automatic, still fairly unusual.
I've never heard the word saloon car used. But maybe this is different amongst people who are interested in cars. Like people who know support columns? 
I appreciate your responses!

@Oikofuge
Thanks for your response.
 How I miss the 'saloon car' or 'restaurant car', with tablecloths and real cutlery, then later the 'buffet car' on trains! Now it's a caf√©-bar, just a counter top. 
Didn't pubs once have a 'public bar', complete with sawdust and spitoons, and a 'saloon bar' - this was more comfortable place where the ladies sat.

@Oikofuge
Etymology always welcome!

@Jane Wheelaghan

Yes, the public bar was a place where you stood at the bar; the saloon bar was often accessible through the public, and had tables and stools, or perhaps even (gasp) banquette seating. It was the place a guy might go (sheepishly) with his girlfriend, or where, as you say, groups of ladies gathered. There was usually also one old guy with a dog, sitting in the corner, quietly nursing a pint. If it was a fairly small space, it was called "the snug [bar]", and it would be pretty much staked out by the regulars. Dominoes would drop from shocked, nerveless fingers if a stranger should poke his head through the door.
Nowadays saloon bars are more usually called "lounge bars", presumably to make them sound a bit more appealing.

My local pub is still configured that way, though the distribution of clientele is now a little different. (Then again, my local pub has had the same embossed wallpaper for the last fifty years ...)

@Jane Wheelaghan

Clearly, there are some people who are more interested and others who are less interested in cars on both sides of the pond, and all over the world. You kind of remind me of our former regular Nancy from Lexington Avenue, who famously never had to drive a car, living in NYC, and had zero interest in them.  (That‚Äôs another thing that I‚Äôm ‚Äúgobsmacked‚Äù by, the fact that you Brits don‚Äôt say ‚Äúzero‚Äù.)

As for the support columns, the third column is a mandatory safety feature legislated quite a while ago because of rollovers.  If you‚Äôve been in a rollover since that change happened, you‚Äôre grateful. If it happened before that, you‚Äôre probably not around to have an opinion. 

By the way, there was a baseball clue and two American football clues today. Did you get any of them?

@Steve L
Actually, we are saying zero more now. We teach small children to say zero, one, two, three and avoid saying OH (as in letter O) and I have heard 'zero interest' used. People still tend to use OH when saying telephone numbers. 
I must have got the sports clues with the crossers, because I didn't notice.
I wouldn't have known them, but I have used ERA and another 3 letter one that I can't remember now! 
I'm sorry Andrzej isn't here to commiserate with.

"Zero" as a number was what I was taught during the 1960s---I learned the words "innumerate" and "illiterate" from my primary-school teacher at a tender age, when some of my little compatriots called the number zero either "nothing" or (worse) "oh".

"Zero" used as a noun modifier (ie, in an adjectival role) in the sense of "no, not any" has actually been around in BrE for decades---the OED has a citation from "Peace News" (a UK publication) for the expression "at zero notice" in 1978. That's certainly a usage that's familiar to me, though I'd have guessed it was more recent.

@RozzieGrandma Thank you! I am going to read this novel as I have been looking for some summer reading.

Also, you're my neighbor (I live in Milton and love Rozzie unconditionally).

@Rich in Atlanta

I'm stuck trying to parse the RATES ART...one.

@Mean Old Lady

I'm guessing Arte Johnson?

@Mean Old Lady

I keep Jane Eyre on all my devices, just in case. I can read it on my phone in the dr's waiting room or exam room. I can read it while waiting for a flight to come in when I'm picking someone up; I can read it anywhere at any time. Once I started reading ebooks, I realized they are there as well, and I can re-read, continue reading, or start reading all sorts of new books on my phone while stuck or waiting anywhere. I thought the small screen would make it difficult, but once I get into a story, I'll read it on my thumbnail if it captivates me! So, although I prefer the hard copy, I always travel with my full library now.
